DOC.brief_summary: It is often clinically impossible to differentiate children with an isolated snoring from those with OSA. The diagnosis of OSA is currently based on nocturnal, laboratory-based polysomnography. This expensive examination is poorly accessible due to appointments delays at hospital. Our study is designed to compare the characteristics of a home polysomnography versus standard polysomnography for the diagnosis of pediatric OSA.
DOC.brief_title: Obstructive Sleep Apnea Syndrome (OSA) and Getemed
DOC.criteria: Male and female subjects, aged 2 to 6 years old, requiring a polysomnography or admitted for intense snoring or suspected sleep apnea Parents must have signed the inform consent form and be covered by the National Health Insurance Program. Parents opposed to the study.
